column2: What should you do if you break down on a level crossing, even if the lights haven't yet begun to flash?
column3: Leave your vehicle and get yourself and any passengers well clear
column4: Continue down the track and attempt to signal any oncoming trains
column5: Tell others what the issue is
column9: Getting everyone out of the vehicle and away from the crossing should be your first priority following a breakdown on a level crossing. Warn the signal operator via the railway telephone (if one is present), and only attempt to move the vehicle if the alarm signals are not yet on.

column2: You arrive at the scene of an accident and find someone has suffered a burn which needs to be treated. How long should the burn be cooled for?
column9: A burn should be cooled for at least 20 minutes. Cool it with a cool, clean, non-toxic liquid. Water ideally. You should also check the casualty for shock.

column2: You arrive at the scene of an incident. Several people are badly injured. After turning on your hazard lights and ensuring all engines are off, what should you do?
column3: Wave down other motorists for help
column4: Pull any casualties away from the vehicle(s)
column5: Provide sweet drinks for anyone injured
column9: You shouldn't assume someone else has already contacted the emergency services, and should phone them yourself. It's also important to make sure there is no further danger. Check that engines are off and that hazard warning lights are turned on, reducing the risk of fire or further collision.

column2: You are approaching a long tunnel. Which of these should you do?
column4: Lower your sun visor and put your sunglasses on
column6: Tune your radio to the frequency shown on signs
column9: You'll often see signs for local radio channels as you approach a tunnel. These radio stations warn of traffic, incidents, or congestion within the tunnel. Some radios have settings allowing them to automatically pick up these signals. Ensure tuning the radio doesn't distract you. Using these radio stations will give advance warning of hazards within the tunnel, preventing issues from escalating. Fire is the greatest risk in a tunnel due to risk of suffocation from smoke.

column2: What should you do if your car catches fire in a tunnel, but is still driveable?
column3: Continue out of the tunnel if possible
column4: Leave the engine running and exit the vehicle
column5: Stop as far to one side of the tunnel as possible
column6: Stop and walk to the nearest emergency telephone
column9: If it's possible to continue on without causing further danger, you should continue to drive out of the tunnel. Smoke gathers in tunnels, presenting risk of suffocation.

column2: There has been a road traffic accident and someone is bleeding from their arm. There is nothing embedded in the wound. How should you help this person?
column3: Dab the wound with a cloth
column4: Raise their arm and apply pressure
column6: Lower their arm and apply pressure
column9: The casualty should be laid down if possible, and the wound should be checked for debris. Use a clean material to apply pressure to the wound without pressing any debris into the wound. If you can, raise the arm above heart level to slow blood loss.

column2: What should you do if your car catches fire in a tunnel, but is NOT driveable?
column3: Close the windows and stay in the vehicle
column4: Turn on your hazard warning lights, leave the vehicle, then call for help
column5: Turn off your lights and leave the vehicle
column6: Leave the engine running and leave the vehicle
column9: While the best option is usually to continue driving, this is sometimes not possible. Pull over at an emergency point (if there is one), switch on our hazard warning lights, and leave the vehicle to call for help. An on-board fire extinguisher may be enough to deal with small fires, but leave large fires to the professionals.

column2: Following an incident, a casualty has a bleeding arm but can move it freely. Why should you ask them to move it into a raised position?
column3: To allow emergency services to recognise them
column4: To reduce blood flow and bleeding
column6: To prevent them from touching other people
column9: Raising the arm above heart level will reduce the flow of blood and lessen blood loss. You should make sure the arm isn't broken before raising it, as this could lead to further injury.

column2: Following an accident, an unconscious injured person has been placed in the recovery position. Their breathing is normal. What else should you do?
column4: Lower their arms to their sides
column6: Press down between their shoulder blades
column9: You should ensure their airway remains clear, monitoring their condition until medical help arrives. Unless there is further danger, do not move the casualty.

column2: You are driving behind a lorry on the motorway. A large box falls from the vehicle onto the road. How should you react?
column3: Continue until the next emergency telephone and report it
column4: Follow the driver and flash your lights to get their attention
column5: Pull onto the hard shoulder and retrieve the box
column6: Stop your car near the box until police arrive
column9: Given the size of their vehicles, it's not uncommon for lorry drivers to miss seeing objects falling from their vehicles. If the driver doesn't stop following this happening, don't attempt to rescue the object. Instead, stop safely on the hard shoulder and report the hazard on an emergency telephone.

column2: An adult isn't breathing at the scene of a crash. To save the casualty, you must administer chest compressions. What is the correct chest compression depth?
column9: A compression depth of 5-6 centimetres is correct. Place both hands in the centre of the casualty's chest and give two chest compressions every second (120 per minute). This maintains circulation in adult casualties who aren't breathing properly.

column2: You have broken down on a motorway and must use the emergency telephone. What will you be asked for?
column9: While on the emergency telephone, the operator will ask for your vehicle details and the reason for the breakdown. Whilst on the phone to the operator, you should face traffic so you can see what's coming.

column2: A motorcyclist has been involved in an accident and is unconscious in the middle of the road. There are no other people or vehicles involved. What should you do first?
column3: Pull the rider out of the road
column6: Reassure the rider that everything will be fine
column9: Warning other traffic should be your first priority, ensuring there is no risk of further collision. Turn on your hazard warning lights to warn other drivers, and ensure all engines are turned off to reduce risk of fire. The motorcyclists is in a very vulnerable position, and you should ensure that in helping them you don't put yourself or others at risk.

column2: How can you help a driver suffering from shock?
column3: Ask who is at fault for causing the accident
column5: Give them a warm, sugary drink
column9: You should call the emergency services to come and help, then reassure the driver, staying with them until the emergency services arrive. The casualty may have injuries that aren't visible, so avoid moving them unless there is further danger.

column2: In which circumstances should a motorcyclist's helmet be removed following a crash?
column4: Immediately, unless they are visibly in shock
column9: You should not remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it is absolutely necessary. Doing so could cause further injury, and they may be suffering from shock. Reassure them with confidence that they will be okay, but don’t let them eat.

column2: There has been an accident involving a motorcyclist. The motorcyclist is unconscious and is lying in the middle of the road. Traffic has stopped and doesn't pose a threat. How should you help?
column9: You should call the emergency services to ensure the motorcyclist gets medical attention as soon as possible. If you cannot phone them yourself, ask someone nearby to do it. You should not move a casualty or remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it is entirely necessary.

column2: Which of these is an appropriate time to use your hazard warning lights?
column3: When driving at night without headlights
column4: If you need to stop and are temporarily obstructing traffic
column5: While travelling slowly to read road signs
column9: Unless being used to warn traffic behind of a hazard or obstruction ahead on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway, hazard warning lights should not be used while moving. They should not be used to warn of illegal or dangerous parking.

column2: What should you do if a warning light comes on while driving?
column4: Continue if there are no visible issues
column5: Have the issue looked into as soon as safely possible
column6: Hope the issue will resolve itself
column9: Warning lights tell you of engine faults and other problems. You should be able to identify any warning light that comes on because they can indicate problems that make your car unsafe to drive. Get a qualified mechanic to check the problem if you're unsure.

column2: If a car is displaying a 'help' pennant, what does it mean?
column3: The driver is more than likely a disabled person
column4: The driver is a rescue patrol officer
column5: The driver is qualified in first aid
column6: The driver is from another country
column9: In the event that a disabled driver can't walk to an emergency phone following a breakdown, the best course of action is for them to stay in their vehicle, turn on their hazard warning lights, and await help. The 'help' pennant indicates when a disabled driver needs assistance.

column2: What must you do if you damage a garden wall with your car, but no one sees?
column3: Report the collision to the police within 24 hours
column4: Tell your insurance company later that day
column5: Tell the owners of the house the next day
column6: Tell someone in the neighbourhood what happened
column9: You should report the collision to the police as soon as possible, and never later than 24 hours afterwards.

column2: You are driving through a tunnel when the traffic ahead slows down and stops. What should you do?
column3: Leave only a small space between you and the vehicle in front
column4: Ignore any signage in the tunnel
column5: If possible, make a U-turn and exit the tunnel
column6: Maintain a safe distance from the vehicle in front of you
column9: Keeping a safe gap between you and the vehicle in front is important, even when moving slowly or stopped in a queue. In a tunnel, leaving space is important for the usual safety reasons, but will also help if you need to manoeuvre around a broken down vehicle.

column2: Following an incident, a small child isn't breathing. You need to administer CPR which include giving rescue breaths. How should you breathe into the child's mouth?
column9: Children and infants have more delicate ribcages than adults, so, after checking their airway is clear, you should use a single hand on their chest (just two fingers for an infant) when giving chest compressions. You should also begin mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, breathing gently until they're able to breathe.

column2: What should you do if you break down in a tunnel?
column3: Stand behind your vehicle and wave traffic past
column4: Stay near your vehicle and warn oncoming traffic
column5: Turn on your hazard warning lights, then call for help
column6: Call the police and stay in your vehicle
column9: You should turn on your hazard warning lights and call for help. In a tunnel, using an emergency telephone usually gets the breakdown sorted sooner. Breakdowns in tunnels can cause severe congestion and danger.

column2: A vehicle has collided with your car What information should you find out if someone is injured and your car is damaged?
column3: What the other driver does for a living
column4: Whether the other driver has a full licence
column5: The name, address, and phone number of the other driver
column6: Where the other driver was going
column9: You should find out the name and address of other involved drivers, as well as the registration numbers of any vehicles involved. The aftermath of a collision can be stressful, but you should try to remain calm. Take pictures of the scene and make note of the positions of vehicles involved. You may need this information for an insurance claim.

column2: Once an area is safe following an incident, how can you look after any casualties?
column5: Keep them in the same position
column6: Help them away from any vehicles
column9: Casualties could have unseen or internal injuries, and moving them could make these worse. It's best not to move them unless staying where they are puts them at further risk.

column2: A collision has taken place in front of you. What is the first thing you should do to help an injured person lying in the middle of a busy road?
column4: Roll them into the recovery position
column6: Check to see if they're in shock
column9: Further collision and vehicle fire are the two most immediate dangers. Warn other traffic by turning on your hazard warning lights (and by placing an advance warning triangle anywhere but on a motorway) and turn off engines to reduce risk of fire. Don't put yourself at risk doing this.

column2: When should you move a casualty who's unconscious but breathing?
column3: When bystanders are there to help
column5: Only if there is further danger
column6: Only when an ambulance has been called
column9: Casualties could have internal injuries or other hidden ailments. Moving them could make these worse, and so casualties should not be moved unless staying put presents a danger. Additionally, only if it's absolutely necessary should a motorcyclist's helmet be removed.

column2: In a long tunnel, what might warn you of an incident or congestion ahead?
column6: Yellow hatch markings on the road
column9: Variable message signs (usually overhead or on the walls) give instructions and warnings about tunnel traffic conditions. Keep watch for the signs changing, and be prepared to stop if they warn of a hazard ahead. Incidents can quickly spiral out of control in congested tunnels, so be wary.

column2: If someone is unconscious following an accident, what is the first thing you should do?
column4: Put something soft under their head
column9: Remember the DR ABC acronym when arriving at crashed where people are injured. Danger (remove risk of further collision or fire), Response (call emergency services), Airway (check their airway is clear), Breathing (check their breathing), Compressions (give chest compressions). Continue providing first aid until the emergency services arrive.

column2: A pedestrian suffers a leg injury following an accident. The leg is bleeding heavily, although it isn't broken and nothing is embedded in the wound. What should you do to help?
column3: Raise the leg to reduce the bleeding
column4: Lay both legs flat on the ground
column5: Get them a drink of water
column9: Raising the leg above heart level will reduce the flow of blood to the limb, and therefore reduce blood loss. Provided there is no debris in the wound, blood loss can be slowed further with a bandage or clean cloth. Tying something around the leg to reduce blood flow is not advised, as it can lead to permanent damage.

column2: How should you use a hand-held device in your car?
column4: Only if you can steer well one-handed
column5: Only on a well lit road
column9: Except in genuine emergencies, it is illegal to use a handheld mobile phone. Doing so will distract you from the road, and increase risk of an accident.

column2: Which of the following is most likely to be a major distraction while driving?
column5: Looking in your rear view mirror
column9: Tuning your radio stations to local radio, planning your route, and taking regular breaks are just a few ways you should prepare for a long journey. Avoid distractions as much as possible. Handheld mobile phone use is illegal except in emergencies, but even hands-free use can be distracting.

column2: How should you use a satellite navigation device (sat nav) without it affecting your driving?
column3: Only when driving in the countryside
column6: Programme the device before beginning your journey
column9: Satellite navigation systems (sat nav) are very useful for unfamiliar journeys, but they can also be distracting. Looking at them could cause you to lose control or miss a hazard ahead. Ensure you're stopped in a safe place before attempting to input information or adjust them.

column2: What should you do before emerging right onto a dual carriageway?
column4: Ensure there is enough room behind you for a second vehicle
column5: Ensure the central reservation is wide enough for your vehicle
column6: Come to a complete stop and select a low gear
column9: You should ensure the central reservation is deep enough to protect your vehicle before emerging right onto a dual carriageway. If it's not, treat the dual carriageway as a single road, and ensure you check both directions before emerging. Not doing this could cause a collision by placing some or all of your vehicle in the path of approaching traffic.

column2: You're approaching a set of traffic lights which have been on green for some time. What should you do?
column9: Always consider when approaching traffic lights on green that they could change to red. Be prepared in case they change and you have to stop, especially if the lights have been green for a while.

column2: While driving on a wet road, you suddenly need stop the car due to an emergency. What should you do to keep safe?
column3: Brake sharply and apply the handbrake
column4: Wave your arm out of the window to warn other drivers
column6: Keep your hands securely on the steering wheel
column9: Paying attention to your surroundings makes it more likely you'll spot hazards early. This means you'll react earlier too, and can keep better control of the vehicle in emergencies. Ensure you keep both hands on the steering wheel to maximise control.

column2: How would using a mobile phone while driving affect you?
column4: It will allow you to drive more carefully
column5: You won't be able to see as well
column9: Even using a hands-free kit can leave you distracted. The person speaking on the other end of the phone can't see the road you're driving and won't know when you need to concentrate, or when a hazard presents itself. The best course of action is to stop in a safe place before making or taking a call.

column2: Before making a U-turn in the road, what should you do?
column3: Glance over your shoulder to check for any oncoming vehicles
column4: Signal by using or arms or indicators
column5: Select a higher gear than you normally would
column6: Select a lower gear than you normally would
column9: Before you perform a U-turn, slow down and have a look to see if the road is clear in both directions. Ensure there is enough space in the road to safely perform the manoeuvre.

column2: What should you do if you get lost in a busy area?
column3: Keep moving and open a map on your phone
column4: Shout to other cars for advice
column5: Stop in the road and ask a pedestrian
column6: Stop somewhere safe and check a map
column9: You should always find a safe place to stop before checking a map or asking for directions.

column2: What should you do before moving out on to the road from a parked position?
column4: Pull out and then look around
column6: Check your rear view and side mirrors to see what's around
column9: You should check your exterior and interior mirrors to make sure the road is clear before moving off. Check your blind spots too, and be prepared to use arm signals if you feel other drivers might not understand your intentions.

column2: You're driving on a narrow country road and see a cyclist ahead. How should you pass?
column3: Pass as close to them as possible
column4: Accelerate past as quickly as possible
column5: Only pass if it is safe, leaving plenty of room
column6: Sound your horn as you pass them
column9: Cyclists often need to weave around potholes, and sometimes need to adjust their course to correct their balance. Allow them plenty of room when you overtake, and pay close attention to the road ahead, looking for farm entrances or driveways where vehicles might pull out.

column2: Why do these yellow lines sometimes appear on the road?
column3: To make you aware of how fast you're going
column4: To help you keep the correct distance from the vehicle in front of you
column5: To guide you to the correct lane
column6: To inform you of the distance to the next exit
column9: These lines are a form of traffic calming measure. They are often present just before roundabouts and dangerous junctions. They prompt you to reduce your speed. You should look ahead and do this in good time.

column2: In which of the following situations are you permitted to use a mobile phone in your car?
column9: Except in genuine emergencies, it is illegal to use a handheld mobile phone. Hands-free kits make phone use possible, but are still distracting. The safest approach is to stop in a safe place before making or receiving a call. Your hands will also be free to take notes if needed.

column2: It starts to get dark while you're driving. Why should you switch on your lights?
column3: To make your dials light up
column4: To see and be seen more easily
column5: Because the street lights are on
column6: Because everyone else is doing it
column9: When visibility is poor during the day, it may be necessary to turn on your headlights and tail lights to help other drivers spot you. This is especially true in early morning or in late afternoon, when the operation of streetlamps might not be timed optimally to help drivers see clearly.

column2: You're driving on the motorway and start to feel sleepy. What should you do?
column3: Stop for a rest on the hard shoulder
column4: Drink an energy drink to get you through
column5: Leave at the first opportunity and find a safe place to stop
column9: Fresh air can help keep you alert when you begin to feel tired, but your first priority should always be using the next service area or motorway exit to find a safe place to rest.

column2: How should you approach this bridge?
column9: Slow down and exercise caution. The bridge is narrow, so passing an oncoming vehicle may not be possible. There is also no footpath, so keep an eye out for pedestrians in the road.

column2: What should you do if you can't get a clear view behind you while reversing?
column4: Open the door to see behind you
column5: Lean out of the window and look behind
column6: Look only in the nearside mirror
column9: Ensure you can see all around your vehicle before attempting to turn your car around. Get someone to guide you if you're unable to get a good look around.

column2: What should you do if your mobile phone starts ringing while you're driving?
column3: Pull up at the nearest kerb
column6: Check to see who's calling you
column9: Using a mobile phone or a similar device while driving or riding is against the law, except in the case of an emergency. For your safety, you should switch off your mobile phone before leaving and set it to voice mail. If your phone rings because you forgot to turn it off, ignore it. When you've come to a safe stop, you can check your phone and, if necessary, return the call.

column2: What is a 'blind spot'?
column3: An area that isn't covered by your headlights
column4: The area covered by your right-hand mirror
column5: An area not visible in your mirrors
column6: The space right behind the driver's seat
column9: Even modern vehicles have blind spots, areas of the vehicle's surroundings not visible through its mirrors. It's therefore essential that you look around to check these areas are clear when necessary.

column2: What should you do before stopping your car?
column9: Before pulling over or coming to a stop, always check your mirrors to see who is behind you. Don't forget to use your indicators if pulling off or stopping by the road.

column2: The windscreen pillar is hindering your view at a junction. Which of the following vehicles should you particularly keep an eye out for?
column9: Approaching motorcyclists, pedestrians, and cyclists can be entirely obscured by windscreen pillars. Take extra time to look for these road users. Don't assume a quick glance is enough.

column2: You're driving behind an LGV (Large Goods Vehicle). Why should you keep well back?
column4: The LGV driver will see you in their mirrors
column5: So you can take corners quicker
column6: To leave space for other cars
column9: LGV and van drivers don't have rear view mirrors. Remember to stay well back from them, because if you can't see their side mirrors, they can't see you. This will also help you see more of the road.

column2: What could happen if you hang objects from your rear-view mirror?
column4: You could be distracted or have your view blocked
column9: Anything dangling from your rear view mirror or stuck to your windscreen could distract you from driving properly. Make sure you can see through your windscreen clearly.

column2: Why should you use your mirrors after you've spotted a hazard up ahead?
column3: To see what's ahead of you
column4: To check to see if you can do an emergency stop
column5: To check whether you can accelerate
column6: To assess the situation around you and react accordingly
column9: You should be checking your mirrors regularly, ensuring you always know what's ahead, beside, and behind you. Doing this will help you anticipate what might happen next, helping avoid and prevent hazards. It's especially important to check your mirrors when you spot a hazard.

column2: In which of the following situations would windscreen pillars hinder your view of the road?
column9: Smaller vehicles and road users - pedestrians, motorcyclists, and cyclists - can be hidden by your windscreen pillars. Be sure to move your head to look past them to check the road at bends and junctions.

column2: In which of the following situations should you NOT overtake?
column4: When approaching a dip in the road
column9: Prior to overtaking, consider if it’s really needed. If you can’t see far enough, keep back and wait for a better place to pull out.

column2: You intend to turn right at a junction but your view is blocked by parked vehicles. What should you do?
column3: Reverse away from the junction and find another route
column4: Move forward quickly to get a clear view
column5: Get out and have a look at what's approaching
column6: Stop at the junction, then edge forward until you have a clear view
column9: Buildings, parked cars, and trees often restrict visibility at junctions. To ensure emerging is safe, edge forward slowly to look past obstructions. Ensure you don't cause other drivers to change speed when you pull out.

column2: Diamond-shaped traffic signs apply to which type of driver?
column9: Diamond-shaped traffic signs are specific to tram drivers. However, drivers of other vehicles should know what they mean so they're aware of what the tram driver may do and what their priorities are.

column2: Which of the following types of road users do tram rails put most at risk?
column9: Tram rails are more slippery than tarmac, and could potentially cause cyclists to lose their balance or fall. Additionally, narrow bicycle wheels can get stuck in tram rails, causing them to wobble, stop, or lose their balance.

column2: You want to turn right in a one-way street that has two lanes. Which lane should you use?
column4: You can't turn right in a one-way street
column9: When turning right on a one-way street, you should position yourself in the right-hand lane. This way, anyone not turning can pass on your left. Ensure you indicate in good time, and switch lanes early to let everyone know your intentions.

column2: When driving at night towards oncoming traffic, which lights should you use on a national speed limit road?
column9: Full-beam headlights can dazzle other drivers. Only use them when you're sure other road users won't be dazzled.

column2: What should you do when following another vehicle at night on an unlit road?
column9: The drivers of vehicles ahead could be dazzled if you drive behind them with your full-beam headlights on. Ensure your lights are dipped when following other vehicles at night, and leave an amount of space appropriate for the conditions

column2: You're being followed closely by a driver who is trying to overtake you. How should you react?
column3: Accelerate to get away from them
column4: Move towards the car in front, giving the overtaking driver nowhere to go
column5: Wave at the overtaking driver to give them permission to pass
column6: Maintain your course and speed, allowing them to overtake
column9: Responding incorrectly to impatient drivers can cause hazards and collisions. You should maintain your course and allow the driver behind to overtake. Slow down if necessary.

column2: Why is a loose filler cap on your fuel tank dangerous?
column3: It could leak fuel, making the road slippery
column5: Your vehicle's exhaust emissions will increase
column6: Your vehicle will be less efficient
column9: An improperly secured filler cap can cause fuel to spill, usually at junctions, roundabouts, and on bends. Spilled fuel makes the road surface slippery. This is especially true during long periods of dry weather, when there's been no rain to wash away previous spills.

column2: Why shouldn't you follow this vehicle too closely?
column5: Your view ahead will be reduced, and the lorry driver won't see you
column6: You will be distracted by words on the rear doors
column9: Maintaining your distance will give you a better view of the road ahead. This will allow you to see any potential hazards and give you more time to respond.

column2: An LGV (Large Goods Vehicle) carrying a heavy load intends to overtake you, but is taking a long time to do so. How should you react?
column4: Slow down to let them pass
column9: A long lorry carrying a heavy load will take longer to pass you than a car, particularly if the road is uphill. Enable the lorry to pass by slowing down.

column2: Why shouldn't you gesture people to cross, by waving or otherwise, at pedestrian crossings?
column3: Another vehicle may be endangering them
column4: They might think you're making a rude gesture
column5: It will increase your journey time
column6: They may not all be ready to cross
column9: Reduce your speed and get ready to stop if you see people waiting at a pedestrian crossing. Don't prompt them to cross the road by gesturing to them. This could be potentially dangerous as other drivers may not be able to stop in time if they fail to see the pedestrians.

column2: Which driving style increases risk for all road users?
column9: Questioning the actions of other road users is defensive driving, and can help you predict possible hazards and react accordingly. The opposite driving style is competitive driving. This increases the risk of collision for all other nearby road users.

column2: You are in slow-moving traffic. What action should you take if the driver behind you is too close?
column4: Ignore them and continue as you were
column5: Move towards the centre of the road to prevent them passing
column6: Indicate left and wave for them to pass you
column9: Drivers following too closely increases the risk of collision, as there's less time for them to brake if you suddenly need to stop. The best thing to do is slow down, increasing the gap in front of you. Doing this lessens the odds that you'll have to stop suddenly, giving you more space to brake in case of a hazard. This is an example of defensive driving.

column2: What is 'tailgating'?
column3: Keeping rear fog lights on even in broad daylight
column5: Opening the boot or rear door of a car
column6: Driving too closely behind another vehicle
column9: When a driver or rider follows the vehicle in front of them too closely, it is referred to as 'tailgating.' It's unsafe because it limits their view of the road ahead. It leaves no room for error if the vehicle in front of them unexpectedly slows down or stops. Tailgating is often the primary cause of rear-end accidents and pile-ups.

column2: How should you deal with an unmarked junction?
column3: Stop the car, get out and have a look
column5: Accelerate, looking left and right quickly
column6: Slow down or stop, then look both ways
column9: You should be cautious at unmarked junctions, especially where obstructions - such as hedges, parked cars, and buildings - block your view. In summer months, foliage may have grown to obstruct your view further, so take extra care.

column2: You're driving behind a vehicle on a wet road. What time gap should you leave between your vehicle and the one you're following?
column9: The grip of your tyres on the road will be reduced by water. In rainy weather, the two-second safe separation gap should be increased to four seconds.

column2: When should you use the 'two-second' rule in dry, good conditions?
column3: When ensuring there is enough distance between you and the car in front
column4: When approaching traffic lights on green
column9: The 'two-second rule' can be used to judge the distance between you and the vehicle in front in good conditions. Look ahead for a fixed object - road markings or signs, for example - and begin saying this phrase when the vehicle ahead passes it: 'Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.' This phrase takes two seconds to say, so if you're unable to finish it before passing the object, you're too close.

column2: What does it mean if a bus lane shows no times of operation?
column3: It is only in use during daylight
column4: It is only in use at peak times
column9: The times of operation of a bus lane and the types of vehicles allowed to use it are shown on bus-lane signs. If a sign shows no hours of operation, it is a 24-hour bus lane.

column2: Which of these vehicles may use flashing blue lights?
column9: Blue flashing lights are used by emergency vehicles to provide additional warning of a hazard. If you see or hear one approaching, move out of its way, providing it's safe and legal to do so.

column2: What should you do if you see a flashing amber light at a pelican crossing?
column3: Give way to pedestrians waiting to cross
column4: Give way to pedestrians already crossing the road
column5: Stop and wait for the green light
column9: Pelican crossings are pedestrian-operated signalised crossings. The signals are changed using push-button controls. There is no red-and-amber stage preceding green at pelican crossings. Instead, there is a flashing amber light. This means you must yield to pedestrians who are already crossing the street. However, if the crossing is clear, you can proceed.

column2: A vehicle behind you accelerates and flashes its lights at you. You are already driving at the legal speed limit. What should you do?
column3: Maintain your speed and move out to stop them overtaking
column6: Tap the brakes to let them know they're too close
column9: Blocking another vehicle's progress to enforce a speed limit will only frustrate the driver behind, potentially making the situation more dangerous. You should allow the vehicle to pass when it's safe to do so.

column2: You see flashing blue lights on an ambulance behind you. How should you react?
column4: Pull over when it is safe to do so
column5: Accelerate to speed up the flow of traffic
column9: Pull over to the side of the road so that the ambulance can safely pass. Make sure there aren't any bollards or other hazards in the road that would hinder the ambulance’s progress.

column2: Which colour follows green at a puffin crossing?
column9: Infra-red sensors at Puffin crossings detect when pedestrians are still crossing, and keep the red light showing until they've crossed. There is no flashing amber phase at puffin crossings, setting them apart from pelican crossings.

column2: What can you do to avoid dazzling drivers behind you at night, while waiting in traffic?
column3: Use the clutch and accelerator to maintain your position
column4: Use the parking brake and footbrake
column6: Apply the parking brake and release the footbrake
column9: When possible, you should apply your handbrake while queuing in traffic. Keeping your footbrake depressed can cause your brake lights to dazzle drivers behind.

column2: How can you prevent spillage after refuelling your vehicle?
column3: Avoid fully filling your fuel tank
column4: Tap your fuel gauge to ensure it's working
column5: Use only a locking filler cap
column6: Ensure the filler cap is tightly fastened
column9: Practising filling your fuel tank is a good thing to do while learning to drive. If your instructor does not offer to help you do this, ask them. Learn how to spot the filler cap on your car, how to pull up at the pump, and take care not to overfill your tank to avoid spilling any excess fuel onto the road.

column2: What should you do if a vehicle pulls out in front of you at a junction?
column3: Slow down and be prepared to stop
column4: Move up close to it and flash your lights
column6: Accelerate past it and sound your horn
column9: Planning ahead and anticipating hazards makes you better prepared for the unexpected. Knowing what's around you helps you predict problems that might arise. Other drivers will inevitably make mistakes. Keep calm and react in the safest way possible.

column2: You intend to turn right further down the road. Why should you move into position well in advance to perform this manoeuvre?
column3: So that other drivers have time to plan accordingly
column4: To get a better view of the road
column5: To let other drivers undertake you if they want
column6: To allow drivers to overtake you
column9: You should indicate and move into position for the turn early. The correct position is nearer the centre of the road, allowing vehicles not turning to pass on your left. Giving nearby drivers early warning of your intentions helps prevent hazards.

column2: You need to overtake a horse and rider. What should you do?
column3: Pass slowly and carefully, ensuring the horse doesn't get startled
column5: Sound your horn to let them know you're there
column9: Passing too closely, too loudly, or too quickly can cause horses to startle or panic. Give them plenty of room as you pass, keeping your speed and engine revs low. You may need to go onto the other side of the road to pass safely.

column2: In what situation should you use your horn?
column3: To alert others of your presence
column4: To get the attention of road users you recognise
column5: To let other drivers know they've annoyed you
column6: To make other road users stop
column9: Unless a moving vehicle presents a danger, your horn should not be used between 11:30pm and 7am in built up areas or while stationary. The purpose of the horn is to let other road users know you're there.

column2: Which of the following is a valid reason for flashing your headlights at other drivers?
column3: To let them know you're there
column4: To show you're about to turn
column5: To let them know you're giving way to them
column6: To tell them you are about to pull out
column9: Your headlights should only be flashed to warn other drivers that you're there. They should not be used in frustration, to give others priority, or to greet people. This could cause a misunderstanding, increasing risk of a collision.

column2: What should you do if the red car cuts in front of you?
column3: Sound your horn to show your annoyance
column5: Slow down to leave an appropriate distance between you and the car
column9: It is inevitable that other drivers will make bad decisions and mistakes. Keep calm and don't retaliate or driver aggressively. The safety of you, your passengers, and other road users should always come fire.

column2: What qualifications are needed to supervise a learner driver?
column3: The supervisor must be 21 or older, and have held a full driving licence for one year or more
column4: The supervisor must be an approved driving instructor
column5: The supervisor must be 21 or older, and must have held a full driving licence for three years or more
column6: The supervisor must hold an advanced driving certificate
column9: To supervise a learner driver, you need to be at least 21 years old and have held a full driving licence for a minimum of three years.

column2: Which of these types of cover must your insurance include to allow you to drive on public roads?
column4: Third party, fire, and theft cover
column9: Third-party insurance is the minimum insurance cover required by law. In the event of an incident, this only covers damage to other vehicles and injury to other people, not damage or injury to you and your vehicle. Fire damage and theft are also not covered. Speak to your insurance company about your requirements to determine which type of insurance is best for your needs.

column2: What is the purpose of the Pass Plus scheme?
column4: To teach you how a vehicle's engine works
column5: To improve a driver's fundamental skills
column6: To allow you to drive without insurance
column9: The Pass Plus scheme is designed to enhance the skills of new drivers. It teaches motorway driving and night-time driving, widening your experience. Completing a Pass Plus scheme can result in lower insurance costs.

column2: What is a cover note?
column3: The document issued when delivering your car for its MOT
column4: The document issued before you receive your driving licence
column5: The document issued upon purchasing a new car
column6: The document issued ahead of receiving your official insurance certificate
column9: An insurance cover note can be issued by an insurance company. It provides the same amount of cover as a full insurance policy, but lasts only for a short time (usually one month).

column2: A vehicle registration certificate (V5C) is issued when a car is sold or transferred. Who is legally responsible for updating registration information?
column9: Keeping the details on your vehicle registration certificate (V5C) up to date is your responsibility, and you need to inform the DVLA of any changes. Failing to do this might make selling your vehicle difficult. Details on the V5C include your name, address, and vehicle details.

column2: Under which of these circumstances must you contact the vehicle licensing authority?
column5: When using your vehicle to commute
column9: You must contact the vehicle licensing authority when you sell your vehicle, and if details such as your name or address change. The helps the DVLA keep up-to-date records of vehicle ownership, and allows them to send road tax reminders when renewal is due. The DVLA keeps a history of every vehicle in the country.

column2: What is covered by third-party insurance?
column9: Third party insurance only covers damage to other vehicles. Damage to your vehicle and personal injury are not covered, so, in the event of a collision, you may have to pay for repairs on your own vehicle.

column2: Which of these is a legal requirement for recently qualified drivers?
column3: Being accompanied by an experienced driver on the motorway
column9: Whether you are a new driver or an experienced one, it is your responsibility to make sure you're insured on any vehicle you drive, no one else's.

column2: Under normal circumstances, how long does a valid MOT certificate last?
column5: Three years from the date of issue
column6: One year from the date of issue
column9: MOT test certificates stay valid for 12 months. As it's not feasible to guarantee a test on the same date 12 months later, an MOT test can be taken 1 month before the current certificate expires. The new certificate then lasts 12 months from the date of expiry of the old certificate. Some but not all garages will send reminders to tell you of upcoming MOT tests. Ensure to book your vehicle in promptly

column2: What does the Pass Plus scheme do for new drivers?
column3: Familiarises them with driving in different conditions
column5: Reduce the cost of breakdown cover
column9: The Pass Plus scheme is designed to enhance the skills of new drivers. It teaches motorway driving and night-time driving, widening your experience. The Pass Plus scheme (and other advanced driving qualifications) must be completed with an approved driving instructor. Completing a Pass Plus scheme can result in lower insurance costs.

column2: How long does a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) stay valid?
column6: Indefinitely, until the vehicle is taxed, sold, or scrapped
column9: A Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) lasts until your vehicle is taxed, sold, or scrapped. While off-road, it does not need to be taxed.

column2: As a learner driver, what must you do before driving on a road for the first time?
column4: Sign up with a driving instructor
column9: Learner drivers need to have a signed provisional licence. The license is not considered valid until signed, so this is something you'll need to do before driving for the first time.

column2: When might the cost of your insurance premiums be reduced?
column3: If you're under 25 years of age
column5: Upon successful completion of a Pass Plus course
column9: Young or inexperienced drivers tend to have more expensive insurance The cost then comes down as you get older and have more experience. Pass Plus is an additional driving qualification for new drivers. It improves your driving skills, and can reduce premiums with some insurers.

column2: If a police officer asks to see your documents but you don't have them with you, how long do you have to present them at a police station?
column9: If a police officer asks to see your documents (insurance information, driving license, etc.) but you don't have them with you, you may be asked to show them at a police station within seven days of being stopped.

column2: What's the maximum fine for driving without insurance?
column9: As well as receiving an unlimited fine, you may be disqualified from driving or incur penalty points for driving uninsured.

column2: When is it legal to drive without an MOT certificate?
column3: When the owner gives you permission
column4: When driving to an MOT appointment
column5: For seven days following expiry of the previous certificate
column9: A car is first required to pass an MOT test at three years old (four years old in Northern Ireland). The only time it is permitted to drive a car older than three (or four) years without a valid MOT certificate is when driving to an MOT test, or for repairs ahead of an MOT test. Some vehicles made before 1960 may also be driven without an MOT test, but must be considered in roadworthy condition

column2: Which of the following information is shown on a vehicle registration document (V5C)?
column4: Details of the vehicle's registered keeper
column6: Details of the type of insurance cover the vehicle has
column9: Every vehicle's registration document (V5C) shows details of its registration number, date of first registration, make, colour, engine size, year of manufacture, and chassis number. Also included are details of the current and previous registered keepers.

column2: What is a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN)?
column3: An official notice to the DVSA informing them of the vehicles MOT status
column4: An official notice informing the DVLA that the vehicle will not be used on the road
column5: An official document kept by the police about any traffic violations linked to the vehicle
column6: An official document containing all your insurance information
column9: You must make a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) if you wish to keep your vehicle off-road and untaxed. This stays valid indefinitely, until you tax, sell, or scrap your vehicle.

column2: When are you required to show your insurance certificate?
column3: When asked for it by a police officer
column5: When submitting a Statutory Off-Road Notice (SORN)
column9: When asked to by police, you must be able to provide a valid insurance certificate. If you don't have this with you, you can present it to a police station at a later date. Your MOT certificate and drivers licence may also be asked for.

column2: Who is required to pay vehicle excise duty (road tax)?
column6: The registered keeper of the vehicle
column9: It is the responsibility of the registered keeper of a vehicle to pay vehicle tax, or to make a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) if keeping the vehicle off the road and untaxed.

column2: Which of these is a legal requirement for driving another person's vehicle?
column3: The vehicle must have third-party insurance cover
column4: The vehicle must be insured for your use
column5: Your own vehicle must have insurance
column6: Any insurance documents must be inside the vehicle
column9: You need to make sure that you are properly insured on any vehicle you drive, even if it's not your own. Driving without insurance is illegal. It's good practice to compare several insurance quotes, comparing their features against your needs, before deciding which one is right for you.

column2: What must you do if you receive six points on your first full licence within two years of passing your practical driving test?
column5: Retake both theory and practical tests
column9: Your licence will be revoked if you get six or more points on your licence in your first two years of driving on a full licence. Offences committed before passing also count towards this total. If your licence is revoked, you return to being a learner driver until you again pass both theory and practical tests.

column2: Under which of these circumstances must you contact the vehicle licensing authority?
column3: When taking your car for its MOT
column5: When deteriorating health impacts your driving
column6: When anyone else drives your vehicle
column9: The DVLA keeps up-to-date records of all drivers, riders, and vehicles in the country. If you have a medical condition that could impact your driving ability, you need to let them know. You also need to let them know if a condition causes you to become unfit to drive.

column2: Which of these is a requirement for renewing your vehicle excise licence (Road Tax)?
column3: The chassis number of the vehicle in question
column9: Road tax (also known as vehicle excise duty) can be renewed online or by phone, at the post office, or at vehicle registration offices. You'll need your renewal reminder notice, and may need your MOT certificate.

column2: Which of the following may be invalidated if you drive a vehicle without a valid MOT certificate?
column9: Driving a vehicle without a valid MOT certificate is illegal. There are only two exceptions to this: When driving your vehicle to its MOT test, and when driving your vehicle to get repairs ahead of its MOT test.

column2: What does it mean if your insurance policy says it has an excess of £100?
column3: Your insurance will increase by £100 per year in the event of a claim
column4: You will get a £100 reward for each year without a claim
column5: The insurance company will only pay £100 towards any claim
column6: You must pay the first £100 of any claim
column9: An excess on your policy results in lower monthly or annual insurance costs, but you'll need to pay the excess for any claim you make. For example, if a repair costs £500 and you have an excess of £100, you will pay £100 towards the cost of repair, and your insurer will pay £400.

column2: What does third-party insurance cover?
column9: Third-party insurance only covers damage and injury to others, and does not cover damage or injury to you or your vehicle. It is usually cheaper than comprehensive cover.

column2: Which of these documents is a legal requirement for using a vehicle on public roads?
column9: Illegal use of a vehicle can result in penalty points and a hefty fine. To drive legally, you must have taxed and insured your vehicle, and have a valid driving licence.

column2: What is the purpose of the pass plus scheme?
column3: It allows you to carry more passengers
column4: It teaches you to drive more defensively
column5: It lets you drive on private land
column6: To improve a driver's fundamental skills
column9: The Pass Plus scheme is designed for new drivers. It enhances basic skills and familiarises drivers with motorway driving and driving in different conditions, reducing the likelihood of a new driver being involved in an incident.

column2: What must you do at this junction?
column5: Stop only if there is another vehicle behind you
column6: Stop only if you're turning right
column9: The 'stop' sign has been placed here to encourage proper observation. The view onto the main road is obstructed, so you should stop and take time to thoroughly check your surroundings.

column2: You're driving on a motorway but begin to feel drowsy. What should you do?
column3: Use the hard shoulder as a place to switch drivers
column4: Turn up the radio and drive faster
column5: Take the next exit and find a safe place to rest
column6: Turn up the temperature and close the windows
column9: You should pull over and stop to rest somewhere safe. Before embarking on a long journey, you should plan your journey to take rest stops, leaving earlier if necessary. This helps prevent you becoming tired, and ensures you reach your destination on time.

column2: What should you do if you need to drive but can't find your glasses?
column3: Find an alternative way to get home
column4: Drive at night on roads with street lights
column6: Drive slowly, staying off busy roads
column9: It's imperative that you can see clearly while driving. If you can't find glasses you need to drive, don't drive. Driving without wearing glasses you need is illegal.

column2: How is a person's driving ability affected by their age?
column4: Elderly drivers take longer to respond to hazards
column5: Elderly drivers cannot get car insurance
column6: Elderly drivers won't indicate at junctions
column9: Older drivers might take longer to spot and react to hazards, and may take more time making decisions. Be patient and tolerant of them.

column2: You're driving but begin to feel drowsy. What should you do?
column3: Stop where it is safe and rest as soon as you can
column4: Open the car window so the wind keeps you awake
column5: Turn up the heater to keep you alert
column9: You should pull over and stop to rest somewhere safe. Driving while drowsy or tired increases risk of collision for you and other road users. Short naps and caffeinated drinks can help relieve drowsiness for a short time. You should always plan to take breaks on long journeys, and consider an overnight stay if necessary.

column2: Where would you encounter these markers?
column5: On motorway or dual carriageway signage
column9: Large goods vehicles (LGVs), vehicles over 13 metres long, and rubbish skips on the road must be fitted with markers like these, making them easier to spot, especially at night.

column2: Which of these types of glasses should not be worn while driving at night?
column9: Tinted lenses will further reduce visibility at night, making it more likely you'll miss hazards on the road.

column2: Where shouldn't you overtake?
column6: On a long, straight country road
column9: You should never overtake at a junction or on a bend. Many of these have road signs and markings to indicate that overtaking there is unsafe or illegal. Generally, you should only overtake when you have a clear view of the road ahead and overtaking is necessary. Doing so rarely improves journey time significantly.

column2: Which of the following hazards should the driver of the grey car be most wary of?
column3: Not enough space between nearby cars
column9: There is always a risk when passing parked cars that a car door will open and a person will step out onto the road. You should drive defensively, keeping your speed low, looking for this and other hazards as you pass.

column2: You've been having medication that causes drowsiness as a side effect. You're feeling better but need to continue the medication. What do you do about driving?
column4: Only drive for very important reasons
column5: Ask someone to accompany you as a passenger
column6: Do not drive unless advised it is safe to do so by your doctor
column9: Medicine that makes you drowsy will render you unfit to drive. It's imperative you don't put yourself or other road users at risk, so check with your doctor if you're unsure.

column2: What can you do to prevent tiredness on a long journey?
column3: Make sure you're well fed before setting off
column4: Set the radio to full volume
column6: Drive the whole way without stopping
column9: Long, boring drives confined to a warm, stuffy vehicle can cause you to feel drowsy. Plan your journey to include frequent breaks, helping you stay alert. Doing this will ensure you don't end up fighting to stay awake.

column2: You've just been prescribed drugs that are likely to affect your driving, but you desperately need to get home. What should you do?
column6: Ask someone else to drive you
column9: Medicine that makes you drowsy also means you're unfit to drive. You should find another way home, or ask someone else to drive you.

column2: Why is it important to reduce your speed in this situation?
column3: The next section of road is very narrow
column4: The road surface is about to change
column5: There is a staggered junction ahead
column6: There is a sharp bend ahead
column9: There is a staggered junction ahead, where traffic could be turning off or emerging from the left and right. Be prepared to slow down or stop, as any traffic wishing to turn ahead will have to slow down to do so, and their desired exit might not be readily available.

column2: Which hazard should you particularly keep an eye out for while following this cyclist?
column3: The cyclist could move further into the middle of the road
column9: The cyclist could move toward the centre of the road to regain their balance, or avoid a pothole or other hazard. Give them plenty of room, especially when overtaking, and don't rev your engine to chivvy them along.

column2: Which of these is a dangerous side effect of drinking alcohol?
column6: More attention paid to road hazards
column9: Alcohol severely impairs decision making, coordination, and reaction time, and can cause overconfidence. This makes the road more dangerous for you and everyone around you. Additionally, being caught over the drink-drive limit comes with serious consequences.

column2: While driving, you often see place names painted directly onto the road surface. Why is this?
column4: To warn you about dangerous places nearby
column6: To indicate to you which lane to be in
column9: These words indicate the destinations possible from each lane, letting you know which lane you should be in. They're more common in towns and cities at busy junctions and complex road systems.

column2: What should you do if the car on the left begins reversing onto the street in front of you?
column4: Sound your horn and slow down or stop
column6: Keep driving as it's your right of way
column9: You should reduce your speed and sound your horn to make sure the other driver knows you're there.

column2: You're about to join a main road. What might help if parked cars are restricting your view of the junction?
column4: Making eye contact with other road users
column5: Looking in your rear view mirror
column9: Before emerging from any road onto another, you should ensure it is safe. If your view of the road is restricted by parked cars or other obstructions, reflections in nearby windows could help, as could looking through nearby car windows. Edge forward until you're sure emerging is safe.

column2: What should you expect upon seeing this sign?
column9: There is a sharp, left-hand bend ahead. Approaching this sign, you should slow down and select the correct gear before reaching the turn. Braking sharply just as you reach the turn is more likely to cause your vehicle to skid.

column2: While driving on a dual carriageway, what might it mean if you see a flashing amber light ahead of you?
column3: There is a doctor's car ahead
column4: There is a disabled person's vehicle ahead
column5: There is a fire engine ahead
column9: It isn't recommended for battery-powered vehicles used by disabled people to be used on the carriageways with speed limits in excess of 50 mph, as they're limited to 8 mph. If one is used on the motorway, they're required to have a flashing amber light.

column2: Some illnesses will impact your ability to drive. When this happens, what should you do?
column3: Consult your doctor every time you want to drive
column4: Take only small doses of medicine
column5: Carry all of your medication with you while driving
column6: Ensure you are fit to drive
column9: Some medicines can make you drowsy, affect concentration, or worsen judgement, rendering you unfit to drive. Only drive if you're confident you are fit to do so.

column2: Why is it important not to block the junction on the left?
column3: To leave space for other vehicles to park
column4: So that vehicles can use the junction
column5: So the bus can use it to turn around
column6: So that other vehicles can make a U-turn
column9: Junctions must always be kept clear. Any queuing traffic needs to ensure there is enough space left clear for the junction to be used normally.

column2: You are driving on a narrow country road behind a slow-moving vehicle. You see a junction up ahead on the right. How should you go about overtaking this vehicle?
column3: Drop back, then accelerate quickly to overtake before the junction
column4: Sound your horn to make the vehicle let you past
column6: Only overtake once you're past the junction and it's safe to do so
column9: Never overtake approaching a junction. This could quickly cause a major hazard if a vehicle emerged from the junction during your manoeuvre.

column2: Holders of provisional licences face some restrictions that full licence holders don't. Which of these is a restriction?
column3: They may only drive in daylight
column4: They must be accompanied by a driver qualified for more than 3 years
column5: They must not drive faster than 40 mph
column6: They can only carry passengers in the front seat
column9: Drivers with only provisional licences must display red L plates, be insured on the vehicle they're driving, and be accompanied by a qualified driver. The person accompanying must be at least 21 and have a full licence that they've held for a minimum of three years.

column2: You're feeling angry as a result of an argument you've just had with a friend. What should you do before your start driving?
column3: Start driving but turn up the radio
column5: Don't drive until you calm down
column6: Start driving but open the window
column9: You shouldn't start your journey until you've calmed down. Driving while upset and angry is dangerous, because your concentration will be impacted.

column2: What should you do if you see a cyclist making this hand gesture ahead of you?
column3: Undertake the cyclist before the junction
column4: Sound your horn to let the cyclist know you're there
column5: Overtake on the right before the junction
column6: Reduce your speed and let the cyclist turn right
column9: Don't get close to the cyclist or try to pass them, as this makes the situation dangerous. Stay back from them and give them space and time to turn.

column2: What should you do if you need to drive but have a severe headache?
column3: Give it a few minutes, then try driving
column4: Drive home if you're confident you can stay awake
column5: Take a tablet for the headache before driving
column6: Wait until the headache passes and you are fit to drive
column9: Pain will distract you from driving. The safest thing to do is to wait until your headache has passed before beginning to drive. Additionally, some painkillers can make you feel drowsy. You should avoid driving when drowsy, as it increases risk for you and other road users.

column2: What should you do when approaching a crossroads where the traffic lights have failed?
column3: Stop for any traffic, then continue very cautiously
column4: Continue at your current speed but be prepared to do an emergency stop
column6: Continue through the junction, only stopping for large vehicles
column9: You should treat this situation as you would an unmarked junction. Stop for any traffic already passing through, then continue when you're sure it is safe.

column2: You come across a two-way road divided into three lanes. Why should you take extra care here?
column3: Because the middle lane is for emergency use
column4: Because traffic in the middle lane is allowed to break the speed limit
column5: Because the middle lane is often in poor condition
column6: Because vehicles travelling in either direction can use the middle lane to overtake
column9: The centre lane can be used for overtaking by traffic travelling in either direction, so it's possible oncoming traffic could plan to overtake at the same time you do. Ensure you indicate early and have thoroughly scanned the road ahead before pulling out.

column2: What should you do in a situation where you believe the driver in front has forgotten to turn off their left indicator?
column5: Continue behind them and be aware that they might still turn
column9: Stay behind them and don't overtake. It could be a mistake, but they might be looking for a turning further ahead, or have misjudged the distance to the next junction.

column2: What should you do when approaching motorway roadworks?
column4: Reduce the gap between you and the vehicle in front
column9: Because collisions are more likely around roadworks, you'll often find reduced speed limits in place. You should slow down early and maintain a safe distance between you and other vehicles.

column2: What colour are the reflective studs that separate the lanes on a motorway?
column9: Different coloured reflective studs are fixed to the road at the edges of motorways and between lanes. White studs show the boundaries between lanes. Use reflective studs to identify which lane you're in in the dark.

column2: What happens when a smart motorway is operating?
column4: Advisory speed limits are shown above lanes
column5: Compulsory speed limits are shown above lanes
column6: 30 mph is the maximum speed allowed
column9: Powered signage over the top of an operating smart motorway will tell you the current compulsory speed limit. The speed limit is varied to prevent bunching and aid traffic flow. A speed limit shown above the hard shoulder indicates it's in use as a running lane.

column2: You see these signs above a three-lane motorway. What is being indicated?
column3: Use the hard shoulder only for emergencies and breakdowns
column4: You may drive in the hard shoulder, but must stay under 50 mph
column5: The hard shoulder is in use as a normal lane
column6: The hard shoulder is available for use as a rest area
column9: These signs indicate that the normal running lanes have a compulsory speed limit of 50 mph, and that the hard shoulder is currently only available for use in breakdowns and emergencies. The hard shoulder will sometimes be used as a running lane on smart motorways. If so, it will have a compulsory speed limit shown above it.

column2: You've pulled onto the hard shoulder after suffering a tyre puncture on the motorway. What should you do?
column3: Flag down another driver to help
column5: Change the wheel yourself, but be careful
column6: Change the wheel, but only if you have a passenger to help
column9: Do not attempt to repair the puncture or replace the tyre. You should get out of your vehicle, leaving it as far to the left of the hard shoulder as possible, and walk to the nearest emergency telephone on your side of the road. Phone for help, then return to your car. Stand away from your vehicle and the carriageway, facing up the road to spot any approaching hazards.

column2: What should you do if signs above every motorway lane show flashing red lights?
column9: This indicates that all lanes of the motorway are closing, usually as a result of a major hazard up ahead. You should come to a stop and wait until told to continue. Avoid changing lanes or using the hard shoulder unless there is an emergency.

column2: Where should you stop to rest if you start to feel tired on a motorway?
column9: You should always plan long journeys with frequent breaks in mind to prevent tiredness. If you find yourself feeling drowsy while driving, stop at the nearest service area, or at the next exit, and find a safe place to stop. Do not stop on the carriageway or hard shoulder. The hard shoulder should only be used in emergencies, when you're signalled to top there by a police officer, or when indicated to drive there on smart motorways.

column2: When is it permitted for cars towing trailers to use the right lane on a motorway?
column3: When large vehicles are in the left and centre lanes
column4: Only when they can drive fast enough
column9: Vehicles towing trailers or caravans are not usually permitted to use the right-most lane, but may do so when all other lanes are closed.

column2: You are in the left lane of a motorway. How should you react to traffic joining from the left?
column3: Move into the lane on your right
column4: Turn on your hazard warning lights
column6: Maintain your speed, it's your right of way
column9: Have joining traffic in mind whenever you're on the motorway approaching a slip road. If it is safe to do so, move into the next lane on the right, making more space in the left-hand lane. This makes it easier for others to join the motorway.

column2: What is a motorway emergency refuge area used for?
column3: A safe place to stop in the event of an emergency or breakdown
column4: It's a parking space used by police for watching traffic
column5: Calming down in the event of a road rage incident
column6: For the storage of emergency equipment by road workers
column9: Emergency refuge areas are areas at the side of the motorway that provide shelter and an emergency telephone that connects directly to a control centre. If you pulled over for an emergency but that emergency has now passed, take care re-joining the motorway, especially if the hard shoulder is being used as a normal lane.

column2: While travelling on a motorway, which of these rules applies?
column3: Unless overtaking, stay in the left lane
column4: Do not travel at less than 50 mph
column6: Overtake in whichever lane is has least traffic
column9: Unless you are overtaking a slower vehicle, you should aim to be in the left-hand lane of the motorway at all times. After overtaking, move back into the left-hand lane, ensuring there is enough space between you and the vehicle you've just overtaken.

column2: What does a red cross mean if it's displayed above a motorway hard shoulder?
column3: Stop here to answer the phone
column4: Do not drive in this lane
column5: This lane is for resting only
column6: This lane is for runners and cyclists only
column9: A red cross above the hard shoulder tells you it is not being used as a running lane and is available for emergencies and breakdowns only. These red crosses will only be present in motorways with active traffic management systems, since these sometimes use the hard shoulder as a running lane.

column2: When is it permitted to stop on a hard shoulder?
column3: When you are drowsy and need a rest
column5: In the event of an emergency or breakdown
column9: Only in genuine emergencies is it permitted to stop on the hard shoulder. It should not be used for resting, answering or making a phone call, checking a map, or picking up a passenger. In the event you miss your exit, continue to the next one. Under no circumstances should you reverse on the motorway.

column2: Which of these vehicles is prohibited from using motorways?
column6: Motorcycles with engines larger than 50 cc
column9: Motorway use is prohibited for mobility scooters (weighing less than 254kg), pedestrians, motorcycles under 50 cc, and certain other slow vehicles without permission.

column2: Which lane should you use well before reaching your intended motorway exit?
column9: Signs above or beside the motorway will warn you of upcoming exits a mile before they appear. You'll only have around 50 second travelling at 60 mph before the exit then appears. You should ensure you're in the left-hand lane early to avoid any sudden movements nearer the junction, as these could cause an incident. You'll see a second sign when you're half a mile from the exit, then markers every 90 metres, starting when you're 270 metres from the exit.

column2: When is it permitted to use the hard shoulder?
column9: The hard shoulder is mainly intended for use in emergencies and breakdowns. It may also be used when indicated by roadwork signs, or on smart motorways when a speed limit sign is shown directly above.

column2: You break down on the motorway and move into hard shoulder. You manage to repair your vehicle. How should you rejoin the main carriageway?
column3: Turn on your hazard warning lights and pull onto the carriageway
column4: Pull onto the carriageway before accelerating
column5: Accelerate along the hard shoulder until you're able to join the carriageway
column6: Wait until someone flashes to let you in
column9: Build up sufficient speed to re-join the motorway while signalling right to indicate your intentions. Only pull out from the hard shoulder when you're sure there is a safe gap to pull into, and aim not to affect the speed or direction of others.

column2: You're driving on a three-lane motorway. If studs to your left are red, and studs on your right are white, which lane are you in?
column9: Red studs are found between the hard shoulder and the edge of the carriageway, while white studs are found between lanes. Seeing red on your left and white on your right tells you you're in the left lane. Remember that green studs indicate a slip road, and amber indicates the central reservation. Bright yellow/green indicates roadworks.

column2: What would you expect to find in a motorway contraflow system?
column5: Lanes that are wider than normal
column9: Motorway contraflow systems almost always come with reduced speed limits. You should slow down as soon as you see signs indicating a different speed limit, and be aware that the barrier between traffic flowing in different directions may not be as sturdy as usually found in a central reservation. Lanes may be narrower, traffic may be using the hard shoulder, and broken-down vehicles could obstruct lanes ahead.

column2: How would you warn drivers behind you if you had to brake suddenly on a motorway?
column9: Your hazard warning lights can be used to indicate when traffic up ahead is slowing. If you need to brake suddenly, your brake lights will warn them too. Only keep your hazard warning lights turned on for as long as it takes for others to notice them.

column2: What does this sign mean on a three-lane motorway?
column3: All lanes, including the hard shoulder, are available for use
column4: All traffic should move into the hard shoulder
column5: Do not use the hard shoulder
column6: Use only the three right-hand lanes
column9: This sign indicates that all lanes - including the hard shoulder - are open as running lanes but have a compulsory speed limit of 50 mph. When driving on the hard shoulder like this, look as far ahead as you can for obstructions, as the hard shoulder will still be used for breakdowns and emergencies.

column2: What colour are the reflective stud that appear between a motorway and its slip road?
column9: Different coloured reflective studs are fixed to the road at the edges of motorways and between lanes. Green studs are found to the left of the left-hand lane wherever there is a slip road. Use reflective studs to identify which lane you're in in the dark.

column2: Which lane should you normally use on a three lane motorway?
column9: Regardless of the speed you're travelling at, you should aim to travel in the left-hand lane, using lanes to the right for overtaking only.

column2: On a motorway, where might you find a climbing or crawler lane?
column9: Crawler lanes are often found on steep hills. They're provided for use by slower-moving vehicles, allowing faster vehicles to continue in the normal lanes. This helps keep traffic flowing and prevents large vehicles hindering progress.

column2: On a motorway, what is the left-hand lane used for?
column5: Undertaking slow moving traffic in the lane to your right
column9: The left-hand lane is intended for normal driving, and you should aim to use the left lane whenever possible. Lanes to the right should be used only for overtaking, or as normal driving lanes when indicated by signals. You may find other drivers become frustrated if you drive in the middle or right-hand lanes while the left lane is empty.

column2: What do these motorway signs show?
column3: There is a police control point ahead
column4: They're countdown markers to the next exit
column5: They're distance markers to the next emergency telephone
column6: They're countdown markers to the next bridge
column9: These are countdown markers indicating an upcoming motorway exit. You'll find them positioned 90 metres apart, starting 270 metres from the slip road. If you're planning to take the indicated exit, move into the left-hand lane well before reaching the slip road.

column2: In the event of a breakdown, which direction should you walk in to find an emergency telephone?
column4: The direction indicated by marker posts
column9: Marker posts at 100-metre intervals along the hard shoulder will tell you how far it is to the nearest emergency telephone.

column2: Unless signs inidicate otherwise, what is the national speed limit for cars and motorcycles on motorways?
column9: Unless otherwise indicated by a smart motorway or roadworks sign, the national speed limit for cars and motorcycles on a motorway is 70 mph. The speed limit is reduced for cars and motorcycles towing trailers.

column2: What should you do if you miss the correct motorway exit?
column3: Continue until you see a gap in the central reservation, then turn around
column4: Reverse cautiously using the hard shoulder
column5: Continue and take the next exit
column6: Reverse cautiously in the left lane
column9: If you miss your target exit, continue to the next exit and take a different route. Reversing on a motorway is illegal, as is crossing the central reservation. If you feel you may have missed your exit because your concentration slipped, find a safe place to take a break.

column2: On a motorway, what does it mean if the vehicle in front of you switches on its hazard warning lights for a short period of time?
column3: Police are checking speeds in this area
column4: They are going to move to another lane
column5: Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly
column9: Signs above or beside the motorway will warn you of upcoming exits a mile before they appear.

column2: What should you do if a lorry approaching a crossroads indicates right but moves towards the kerb on the left?
column3: Stay back and give it room
column4: Phone the police and report the driver
column5: Flash to warn them they've signalled incorrectly
column9: Long vehicles need plenty of space to navigate around tight corners or junctions, ensuring both the cab and trailer make it around without touching either kerb (or other obstacles).
